canonical_explanation.text: Reproductive health refers to the total well-being in all aspects of reproduction, including physical, emotional, behavioural, and social dimensions. India launched the Family Planning Programme in 1951 (the first country to do so) to address population growth. This was renamed the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) Programme. Key strategies include creating awareness about reproduction-related aspects, providing education about puberty and reproductive organs, promoting safe and hygienic sexual practices, and making contraception accessible. Population explosion is a major concern; India's population crossed 1 billion in 2000. Contraceptive methods include natural methods (periodic abstinence, coitus interruptus, lactational amenorrhoea), barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms, cervical caps), IUDs (copper-releasing like CuT, Cu7, Multiload; hormone-releasing like Progestasert, LNG-20), oral contraceptives (pills containing synthetic progestogen or oestrogen-progestogen combinations), injectables and implants (e.g., Saheli containing centchroman), surgical methods (vasectomy in males, tubectomy in females). Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is legal in India up to 20 weeks with medical advice. Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs/STIs) include gonorrhoea, syphilis, chlamydiasis, genital herpes, genital warts, hepatitis B, and HIV/AIDS. Infertility can be managed through assisted reproductive technologies (ART) such as IVF-ET (test tube baby), ZIFT, GIFT, ICSI, and AI (artificial insemination). Amniocentesis is a prenatal diagnostic technique that has been banned for sex determination to prevent female foeticide.
rules: Reproductive health encompasses physical, emotional, behavioural, and social well-being related to reproduction
India was the first country to launch a family planning programme (1951), later renamed RCH (Reproductive and Child Health)
Natural contraceptive methods: periodic abstinence (avoiding intercourse during day 10-17), coitus interruptus, lactational amenorrhoea (up to 6 months post-partum)
Barrier methods physically prevent sperm from reaching the egg: condoms, diaphragms, cervical caps, vaults
IUDs: copper-releasing (CuT, Cu7, Multiload 375) increase phagocytosis of sperm; hormone-releasing (Progestasert, LNG-20) make uterus unsuitable
Oral pills contain synthetic progestogen or oestrogen-progestogen that inhibit ovulation and alter cervical mucus; Saheli is a non-steroidal weekly pill
Surgical sterilisation: vasectomy (cutting vas deferens in males) and tubectomy (cutting fallopian tubes in females)
MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) is legal in India up to 20 weeks; essential for cases of contraceptive failure, rape, or foetal abnormalities
STDs: bacterial (gonorrhoea, syphilis, chlamydiasis), viral (genital herpes, genital warts, hepatitis B, HIV/AIDS); condoms provide best protection
ART includes IVF-ET (in vitro fertilisation-embryo transfer), ZIFT (zygote intra-fallopian transfer), GIFT (gamete intra-fallopian transfer), ICSI (intracytoplasmic sperm injection)
Amniocentesis is a prenatal diagnostic technique; banned for sex determination to prevent female foeticide

questions.question_text: Reproductive health refers to:

options.text: Only the absence of reproductive diseases
Total well-being in all aspects of reproduction - physical, emotional, behavioural, and social
Only the ability to produce offspring
The study of reproductive organs only

questions.explanation_correct: According to the WHO, reproductive health means total well-being in all aspects of reproduction - physical, emotional, behavioural, and social. It encompasses much more than just the absence of diseases or the ability to reproduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Absence of diseases is only one aspect. Producing offspring is one function but not the complete definition. Studying reproductive organs is reproductive biology. Reproductive health is a comprehensive concept covering all dimensions.

questions.question_text: Which country was the first to launch a national family planning programme?
questions.explanation_correct: India was the first country in the world to launch a national family planning programme in 1951. This programme was later renamed the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) Programme to broaden its scope beyond just family planning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: China's one-child policy came later (1979). USA and Japan did not pioneer national family planning programmes. India's 1951 initiative was the world's first such programme.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major reason for the population explosion in India?

options.text: Increase in birth rate and decrease in death rate due to improved healthcare
Decrease in both birth rate and death rate

questions.explanation_correct: Population explosion in India is primarily due to a rapid decline in death rate (owing to improved healthcare, better nutrition, and disease control) while the birth rate has not decreased proportionally. This gap between high birth rate and low death rate causes rapid population growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If both rates decreased equally, there would be no explosion. An increase in death rate would reduce population. Immigration is not the primary factor. The birth-death rate gap is the main cause.

questions.question_text: The RCH (Reproductive and Child Health) programme aims to:

options.text: Only provide contraceptives to married couples
Create awareness about reproduction, provide maternal and child healthcare, and promote family planning

questions.explanation_correct: The RCH programme has comprehensive objectives: creating awareness about reproductive health, providing ante-natal and post-natal care, promoting safe delivery, immunisation, family planning through contraception, and educating about STDs and infertility management.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The programme goes beyond just providing contraceptives. Its goal is to stabilise, not increase, population growth. It covers both urban and rural areas. It is a comprehensive health programme.

questions.question_text: Amniocentesis is a technique used for:

options.text: Prenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders by analysing amniotic fluid

questions.explanation_correct: Amniocentesis is a prenatal diagnostic technique where a sample of amniotic fluid is collected and analysed to detect chromosomal abnormalities and genetic disorders in the developing foetus. However, it has been banned for sex determination in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Artificial insemination is a different ART technique. IVF is a fertilisation method. STD detection uses different tests. Amniocentesis specifically analyses amniotic fluid for prenatal diagnosis.

questions.question_text: Amniocentesis has been legally banned in India for sex determination because:

options.text: It poses a high risk to the mother
Its misuse leads to female foeticide
It cannot accurately determine the sex of the foetus

questions.explanation_correct: Amniocentesis has been banned for sex determination in India because it was being misused to identify the sex of the foetus, leading to female foeticide (selective abortion of female foetuses). This contributed to a skewed sex ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While cost and risk exist, they are not the reason for the ban. The technique can accurately determine sex. The ban specifically targets the misuse for sex determination leading to female foeticide.

questions.question_text: Which of the following measures can effectively control population growth?

options.text: Raising the minimum age of marriage and promoting education

questions.explanation_correct: Raising the minimum age of marriage (currently 21 for males and 18 for females in India) and promoting education, especially female literacy, are effective measures for population control. Education empowers individuals to make informed reproductive choices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Early marriage leads to earlier and more pregnancies. Discouraging contraceptives increases birth rates. Reducing awareness worsens the situation. Education and delayed marriage are proven population control strategies.

questions.question_text: India's population crossed the 1 billion mark in the year:
questions.explanation_correct: India's population crossed the 1 billion mark around the year 2000. Despite various family planning measures, the rapid decline in death rate coupled with a still high birth rate led to this milestone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India's population was below 1 billion in 1990 and 1995. By 2005, it was already well above 1 billion. The year 2000 is when India's population first reached 1 billion.

questions.question_text: MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) is legally permitted in India up to:
questions.explanation_correct: In India, MTP is legally permitted up to 20 weeks of pregnancy with the advice of a qualified medical practitioner. It is essential in cases of contraceptive failure, rape, or when the continuation of pregnancy threatens the mother's life or the foetus has severe abnormalities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 8 and 12 weeks are too restrictive and not the legal limit. 36 weeks is near full term and not the legal limit. The MTP Act permits termination up to 20 weeks (with recent amendments allowing up to 24 weeks in special cases).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an objective of the family planning programme?

options.text: Encouraging sex determination of the foetus

questions.explanation_correct: Encouraging sex determination of the foetus is NOT an objective of family planning. In fact, sex determination for the purpose of sex-selective abortion is banned in India under the PCPNDT Act. All other options are legitimate objectives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reducing mortality, promoting contraceptives, and creating STD awareness are genuine objectives. Sex determination is banned and is against the principles of the programme.

questions.question_text: The statutory minimum age for marriage in India is:
questions.explanation_correct: The legal minimum age of marriage in India is 21 years for males and 18 years for females. This law was enacted to prevent child marriage and is an important measure for population control and reproductive health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ages are different for males and females in Indian law. 25/21 and 16/16 are not the correct legal ages. The law specifies 21 for males and 18 for females.

questions.question_text: A couple does not wish to have children for the first two years of marriage but wants children later. Which approach would be most suitable?

options.text: Use of reversible contraceptive methods such as condoms or oral pills

questions.explanation_correct: Since the couple wants to delay pregnancy temporarily, reversible contraceptive methods like condoms, oral pills, or IUDs are most suitable. These can be discontinued when the couple decides to have children.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vasectomy and tubectomy are permanent surgical methods. Complete abstinence is impractical for a married couple. Reversible methods provide temporary contraception that can be stopped when pregnancy is desired.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: MTP is considered unsafe when performed by unqualified persons.
Reason: MTP requires proper medical supervision and sterile conditions to avoid complications.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. MTPs performed by unqualified persons without proper medical facilities can lead to serious complications such as infections, haemorrhage, and even death. Medical supervision ensures safety.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MTP by unqualified persons is indeed unsafe, and the need for medical supervision and sterile conditions is the exact reason why. Both statements are factually correct and causally related.

questions.question_text: Condoms are classified as which type of contraceptive method?
questions.explanation_correct: Condoms are barrier methods of contraception. They physically prevent the sperm from reaching the ovum by creating a barrier. Male condoms are made of latex/polyurethane and cover the penis; female condoms line the vagina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hormonal methods include pills and injectables. Chemical methods include spermicides. Surgical methods include vasectomy and tubectomy. Condoms are physical barriers that block sperm entry.

questions.question_text: An ideal contraceptive should be:

options.text: User-friendly, reversible, with no or minimal side effects
Expensive and requiring regular medical supervision

questions.explanation_correct: An ideal contraceptive should be user-friendly, easily available, effective, reversible, and have no or minimal side effects. It should not interfere with sexual drive, desire, or the sexual act.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Irreversibility is not ideal for most users. High cost limits accessibility. Requiring surgery limits usability. An ideal contraceptive should be simple, safe, effective, and reversible.

questions.question_text: Oral contraceptive pills primarily work by:

options.text: Killing sperm in the female tract
Inhibiting ovulation and altering cervical mucus

questions.explanation_correct: Oral contraceptive pills contain synthetic progestogen or oestrogen-progestogen combinations that primarily work by inhibiting ovulation (preventing the release of eggs). They also alter the cervical mucus to make it hostile to sperm and make the endometrium unreceptive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spermicides kill sperm, not pills. Blocking tubes is done surgically (tubectomy). Pills do not cause abortion. Oral pills work hormonally by preventing ovulation and modifying reproductive tract conditions.

questions.question_text: Copper-releasing IUDs like CuT work primarily by:

options.text: Releasing copper ions that are toxic to sperm and increase phagocytosis
Dissolving the zona pellucida of the ovum

questions.explanation_correct: Copper-releasing IUDs (CuT, Cu7, Multiload 375) release copper ions into the uterine cavity. These copper ions are toxic to sperm, reduce their motility, and increase the phagocytosis of sperm, thereby preventing fertilisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hormone-releasing IUDs (not copper IUDs) release hormones. IUDs do not block the cervix. They do not dissolve the zona pellucida. Copper IUDs specifically work through copper ion toxicity to sperm.

questions.question_text: Vasectomy is a surgical sterilisation procedure in which:

options.text: The fallopian tubes are cut and tied
The vas deferens is cut and tied on both sides

questions.explanation_correct: Vasectomy is a male surgical sterilisation method in which a small portion of the vas deferens (sperm duct) is cut, tied, or sealed on both sides. This prevents sperm from being ejaculated, making the male infertile while retaining normal hormone function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting fallopian tubes is tubectomy (female procedure). Uterus removal is hysterectomy. Prostate removal is prostatectomy. Vasectomy specifically involves cutting the vas deferens in males.

questions.question_text: Lactational amenorrhoea is a natural method of contraception that works because:

options.text: Intense lactation suppresses ovulation and menstruation for up to 6 months after delivery
The uterus becomes permanently non-functional during lactation

questions.explanation_correct: Lactational amenorrhoea is based on the principle that during intense lactation (full breastfeeding), the hormone prolactin suppresses ovulation and menstruation. This natural contraceptive effect is reliable only for about 6 months after delivery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The effect is temporary (up to 6 months), not permanent. Breast milk does not contain spermicides. The uterus is not permanently affected. The mechanism is hormonal suppression of ovulation during intense breastfeeding.

questions.question_text: Periodic abstinence as a natural contraceptive method involves avoiding intercourse during:
questions.explanation_correct: Periodic abstinence (rhythm method) involves avoiding sexual intercourse during the fertile period, which is approximately days 10-17 of a 28-day menstrual cycle. Ovulation occurs around day 14, and the ovum and sperm can survive for a few days, making this window fertile.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Days 1-5 are the menstrual phase. Days 20-28 are in the luteal phase when the egg has usually degenerated. The entire cycle need not be avoided. Days 10-17 encompass the fertile period around ovulation.

questions.question_text: Saheli, the non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill developed in India, contains:
questions.explanation_correct: Saheli is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill developed by CDRI (Central Drug Research Institute), Lucknow. It contains centchroman, which is taken once a week. It has very few side effects and high effectiveness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Synthetic progesterone and oestrogen are used in conventional hormonal pills. Mifepristone is used for medical abortion. Saheli uniquely contains centchroman, a non-steroidal compound.

questions.question_text: Which of the following IUDs releases progesterone to make the uterus unsuitable for implantation?
questions.explanation_correct: LNG-20 (Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD) is a hormone-releasing IUD that releases the progestogen levonorgestrel. This makes the uterine environment hostile for implantation and also thickens cervical mucus. Progestasert is another hormone-releasing IUD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CuT, Multiload 375, and Cu7 are all copper-releasing IUDs that work by releasing copper ions. LNG-20 is the hormone-releasing IUD that releases progestogen to prevent implantation.

questions.question_text: Tubectomy differs from vasectomy in that tubectomy involves:

options.text: Cutting the vas deferens in males
Cutting and tying the fallopian tubes in females

questions.explanation_correct: Tubectomy is a female surgical sterilisation method where a small portion of each fallopian tube is cut, tied, or blocked. This prevents the ovum from reaching the uterus and prevents sperm from reaching the ovum. Vasectomy involves cutting the vas deferens in males.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting vas deferens is vasectomy (male procedure). IUD insertion and hormonal pills are non-surgical methods. Tubectomy is specifically the surgical cutting of fallopian tubes in females.

questions.question_text: Which of the following contraceptive methods also provides protection against STDs?
questions.explanation_correct: Condoms are the only contraceptive method that also provides significant protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs/STIs). They act as a physical barrier preventing the exchange of body fluids between sexual partners.
questions.explanation_incorrect: IUDs prevent pregnancy but not STDs. Oral pills are hormonal contraceptives with no STD protection. Surgical sterilisation prevents pregnancy but not STDs. Only condoms provide dual protection.

questions.question_text: Coitus interruptus is a natural contraceptive method that involves:

options.text: Withdrawal of the penis before ejaculation

questions.explanation_correct: Coitus interruptus (withdrawal method) involves the male partner withdrawing the penis from the vagina before ejaculation, so that semen is not deposited in the female reproductive tract. It is a natural method with a relatively high failure rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spermicidal creams are chemical methods. Complete abstinence is different from coitus interruptus. Diaphragms are barrier methods. Coitus interruptus specifically involves withdrawal before ejaculation.

questions.question_text: Emergency contraceptives (morning-after pills) are used:

options.text: Within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to prevent pregnancy

questions.explanation_correct: Emergency contraceptives (like levonorgestrel or ulipristal) are taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure. They work by preventing or delaying ovulation, or preventing implantation. They are not meant for regular use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Emergency contraceptives are not for regular daily use. They do not treat STDs. They prevent, not enhance, fertility. They are specifically for emergency situations within 72 hours.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is CORRECTLY matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Saheli is correctly matched as a non-steroidal oral contraceptive. It contains centchroman and was developed in India. The other pairings are incorrect: CuT is an IUD (not hormonal), diaphragm is a barrier method (not surgical), and vasectomy is surgical (not barrier).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CuT releases copper ions and is an IUD, not hormonal. Diaphragm is a barrier method placed over the cervix. Vasectomy is a permanent surgical method. Only Saheli as a non-steroidal pill is correctly matched.

questions.question_text: Spermicidal creams, jellies, and foams are classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Spermicidal creams, jellies, and foams are chemical methods of contraception. They contain chemicals that kill or immobilise sperm. They are often used along with barrier methods like diaphragms for increased effectiveness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They are not hormonal as they do not alter hormone levels. They are chemical agents, not physical barriers. They are not natural methods. Spermicides are classified as chemical contraceptives.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a bacterial sexually transmitted disease?
questions.explanation_correct: Gonorrhoea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is a bacterial STD that affects the mucous membranes of the urogenital tract, causing pain during urination and abnormal discharge. Other bacterial STDs include syphilis and chlamydiasis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Genital herpes is caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV). Genital warts are caused by Human papillomavirus (HPV). AIDS is caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). Gonorrhoea is the bacterial STD among these.

questions.question_text: AIDS is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) is caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus), a retrovirus that attacks the immune system, specifically the CD4+ T-helper lymphocytes. It is transmitted through sexual contact, blood transfusion, sharing needles, and from mother to child.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AIDS is not caused by bacteria, fungi, or protozoans. It is caused specifically by HIV, a retrovirus. The virus progressively destroys the immune system, making the person vulnerable to opportunistic infections.

questions.question_text: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium:
questions.explanation_correct: Syphilis is caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum. It is a chronic STD that progresses through primary (chancre), secondary (rash), and tertiary (organ damage) stages if untreated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhoea. Chlamydia trachomatis causes chlamydiasis. Human papillomavirus causes genital warts. Treponema pallidum is the specific causative agent of syphilis.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most effective method to prevent STDs?

options.text: Using condoms and practising safe sexual behaviour

questions.explanation_correct: Using condoms during sexual intercourse and practising safe sexual behaviour (avoiding multiple partners, knowing partner's STD status) are the most effective methods to prevent STDs. Condoms act as physical barriers preventing exchange of body fluids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oral pills and IUDs prevent pregnancy but not STDs. Taking antibiotics regularly is inappropriate and leads to resistance. Condoms combined with safe practices provide the best STD prevention.

questions.question_text: Genital warts are caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Genital warts are caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV). They appear as small, flesh-coloured bumps in the genital area. Some high-risk strains of HPV are also associated with cervical cancer in females.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhoea. Hepatitis B virus causes liver inflammation. HPV specifically causes genital warts.

questions.question_text: HIV can be transmitted through all of the following EXCEPT:

options.text: Casual contact like handshaking, hugging, or sharing food

questions.explanation_correct: HIV is NOT transmitted through casual contact such as handshaking, hugging, sharing food, or using the same toilet. It is transmitted through sexual contact, contaminated blood/needles, and from infected mother to child during pregnancy/delivery/breastfeeding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unprotected sex, contaminated needles, and infected blood transfusion are all confirmed modes of HIV transmission. Casual contact does not spread HIV because the virus cannot survive in saliva, sweat, or tears in sufficient quantities.

questions.question_text: Which of the following STDs is caused by a protozoan?
questions.explanation_correct: Trichomoniasis is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. It causes vaginal discharge and irritation in females. Syphilis and gonorrhoea are bacterial, while genital herpes is viral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Syphilis is bacterial (Treponema pallidum). Gonorrhoea is bacterial (Neisseria gonorrhoeae). Genital herpes is viral (HSV). Trichomoniasis is the STD caused by a protozoan parasite.

questions.question_text: Hepatitis B is classified as an STD because it can be transmitted through:

options.text: Sexual contact and infected body fluids

questions.explanation_correct: Hepatitis B virus can be transmitted through sexual contact with an infected person, sharing needles, blood transfusion, and from mother to child. Because sexual transmission is a significant route, it is classified as an STD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hepatitis A is spread through contaminated food/water, not Hepatitis B. It is not airborne. Mosquitoes do not transmit Hepatitis B. Sexual contact and infected body fluids are key transmission routes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT correctly matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Genital herpes is caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV), NOT Human Papillomavirus (HPV). HPV causes genital warts. This is a common point of confusion. All other pairings are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gonorrhoea-Neisseria is correct. Syphilis-Treponema is correct. AIDS-HIV is correct. The incorrect pairing is genital herpes-HPV; it should be genital herpes-HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus).

questions.question_text: Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to:

options.text: Conceive despite unprotected coitus over a period of time

questions.explanation_correct: Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to produce children (conceive) despite unprotected sexual intercourse over a significant period of time (typically one year). It may be due to problems in the male, female, or both partners.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inability to produce gametes is just one cause of infertility. Infertility is not about the number of children. Menstrual irregularity may contribute but is not the definition. Infertility is the inability to conceive naturally.

questions.question_text: IVF-ET stands for:

options.text: Internal Vitro Fertilisation and External Transfer
In Vitro Fertilisation and Embryo Transfer
In Vivo Fertilisation and Embryo Transplant
Intra Vaginal Fusion and Egg Transfer

questions.explanation_correct: IVF-ET stands for In Vitro Fertilisation and Embryo Transfer. In this ART procedure, eggs and sperm are fertilised outside the body ('in vitro' means 'in glass'), and the resulting embryo is transferred into the uterus. Babies born through this method are popularly called 'test tube babies'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: None of the other expansions are correct medical terms. IVF means fertilisation occurs outside the body (in vitro), and ET refers to transfer of the embryo to the uterus.

questions.question_text: In the GIFT (Gamete Intra-Fallopian Transfer) technique:

options.text: The embryo is transferred into the uterus
The zygote is transferred into the fallopian tube
An ovum collected from a donor is transferred with sperm into the fallopian tube of the female
Sperm is directly injected into the ovum

questions.explanation_correct: In GIFT, an ovum (from a donor or the woman herself) is transferred along with sperm directly into the fallopian tube of the woman. Fertilisation occurs naturally inside the body (in vivo). This is suitable for women who cannot produce ova but have functional fallopian tubes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Embryo transfer to the uterus is IVF-ET. Zygote transfer to the fallopian tube is ZIFT. Direct sperm injection into the ovum is ICSI. GIFT involves transferring gametes (both ovum and sperm) into the fallopian tube.

questions.question_text: ZIFT differs from GIFT in that in ZIFT:

options.text: Gametes are transferred to the fallopian tube
The zygote or early embryo (up to 8 cells) is transferred to the fallopian tube
Fertilisation occurs in the fallopian tube

questions.explanation_correct: In ZIFT (Zygote Intra-Fallopian Transfer), fertilisation occurs in the laboratory (in vitro), and the resulting zygote or early embryo (up to 8 cells) is transferred into the fallopian tube. In contrast, GIFT transfers unfertilised gametes into the fallopian tube.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gamete transfer to the fallopian tube describes GIFT. In ZIFT, fertilisation occurs in the lab, not the fallopian tube. Laboratory procedures are essential. ZIFT specifically involves transferring a zygote/early embryo.

questions.question_text: Artificial insemination (AI) is a technique in which:

options.text: Eggs are fertilised in the laboratory
Semen collected from the husband or a donor is artificially introduced into the female reproductive tract
Sperm is injected directly into the ovum

questions.explanation_correct: Artificial insemination (AI) involves collecting semen from the husband or a healthy donor and artificially introducing it into the vagina or uterus of the female. This is used when the male has low sperm count or ejaculation problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lab fertilisation describes IVF. Surrogacy is a different arrangement. Direct sperm injection into the ovum is ICSI. AI specifically involves artificial introduction of semen into the female tract.

questions.question_text: ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection) is particularly useful when:

options.text: The male has a very low sperm count or defective sperm

questions.explanation_correct: ICSI involves injecting a single sperm directly into the cytoplasm of an ovum. It is particularly useful when the male has a very low sperm count, poor sperm motility, or abnormal sperm morphology, as only one viable sperm is needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For ovulation failure, hormonal treatment or GIFT may be used. Blocked fallopian tubes are addressed by IVF-ET. Endometriosis may require other treatments. ICSI specifically addresses severe male factor infertility.

questions.question_text: A 'test tube baby' is a baby conceived through:

options.text: Natural fertilisation inside the mother's body
In vitro fertilisation where the embryo is grown entirely in a test tube
In vitro fertilisation followed by embryo transfer to the mother's uterus

questions.explanation_correct: A 'test tube baby' is conceived through IVF-ET: fertilisation of the egg by sperm occurs outside the body (in vitro, in a laboratory dish) and the resulting embryo is transferred to the mother's uterus for further development. The baby develops naturally inside the womb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural fertilisation inside the body is normal conception. The embryo is not grown entirely in a test tube; it develops in the womb. It is not cloning. IVF with subsequent embryo transfer to the uterus is the correct process.

questions.question_text: Chlamydiasis is an STD caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlamydiasis is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is one of the most common bacterial STDs. In females, it can cause pelvic inflammatory disease and may lead to infertility if untreated. In males, it causes urethritis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlamydia is not a virus, protozoan, or fungus. It is an intracellular bacterium. Chlamydia trachomatis is the specific bacterial pathogen responsible for this common STD.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Condoms are preferred over oral pills for preventing both pregnancy and STDs.
Reason: Condoms act as a physical barrier and prevent the exchange of body fluids.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Condoms are preferred when dual protection (pregnancy and STD prevention) is needed because they physically barrier against both sperm and pathogenic microorganisms by preventing body fluid exchange.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true because condoms provide dual protection unlike pills. The reason correctly explains how condoms achieve this - by acting as a physical barrier. Both statements are true and causally related.

questions.question_text: Which ART technique would be most suitable for a female who can produce ova but has blocked fallopian tubes?

options.text: IVF-ET (with embryo transfer to the uterus)

questions.explanation_correct: IVF-ET with embryo transfer directly to the uterus is most suitable when fallopian tubes are blocked. The egg is fertilised in the lab and the embryo is placed in the uterus, bypassing the blocked tubes entirely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: GIFT requires functional fallopian tubes for gamete transfer. ZIFT also requires functional tubes for zygote transfer. Artificial insemination requires sperm to travel through the tubes. Only IVF-ET with uterine transfer bypasses blocked tubes.

questions.question_text: Early symptoms of most STDs include:

options.text: Itching, fluid discharge from genitals, swelling, and pain during urination
Skin rashes all over the body only

questions.explanation_correct: Common early symptoms of STDs include itching in the genital area, abnormal fluid discharge from the genitals, slight pain and swelling in the genital region, and pain or burning sensation during urination. However, some STDs may initially be asymptomatic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High fever and joint pain are not typical early STD symptoms. Skin rashes may occur in some STDs but are not the only symptom. Some STDs can be asymptomatic initially, but most do eventually show symptoms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following STDs, if left untreated, can lead to infertility in both males and females?
questions.explanation_correct: Gonorrhoea (caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae) and chlamydiasis (caused by Chlamydia trachomatis) can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease in females and epididymitis in males if left untreated, both of which can result in infertility.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Genital warts may cause cancer but not typically infertility. Genital herpes causes recurrent sores. Hepatitis B affects the liver. Gonorrhoea and chlamydiasis are specifically associated with infertility when untreated.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about assisted reproductive technologies (ART) is CORRECT?

options.text: ART techniques are simple and always have a 100% success rate
ART can help infertile couples but requires specialised medical facilities and trained professionals
ART is only needed when the female has infertility issues
ART replaces the need for adoption entirely

questions.explanation_correct: ART can help many infertile couples achieve pregnancy, but these techniques require specialised medical facilities, trained professionals, and are technically complex. They do not guarantee success, and multiple attempts may be needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ART is not simple and does not have a 100% success rate. ART addresses both male and female infertility factors. Adoption remains an important option alongside ART. The correct statement emphasises the need for specialised medical expertise.
